title: 106_hr409
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1999". It includes findings related to financial assistance management. The Congress finds that there are over 600 different Federal financial assistance programs, some of which have duplicative or burdensome administrative requirements, hindering cost-effective service delivery. Streamlining these procedures will improve services to the public. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, key definitions include Director as the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Federal agency as any agency defined under title 5, Federal financial assistance as aid provided to non-Federal entities, local government as a political subdivision of a State, and non-Federal entity as a State, local government, or nonprofit organization. A nonprofit organization is defined as an entity operated for public interest, not for profit, and uses proceeds to maintain operations. A State is defined as any state within the United States and its territories. The curr_chunk defines terms related to governmental entities, including Tribal government and uniform administrative rule. The curr_chunk outlines the duties of federal agencies. Federal agencies must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment to streamline application procedures, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, designate a lead official, and allow electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs. The agency must ensure recipients provide high-quality information in response to reporting requirements and establish annual goals to measure performance. If agencies cannot comply, the Director will report to the Senate and Governmental Affairs Committee. The Director may extend the period for plan development and implementation for noncompliant agencies for up to 12 months. Each agency must publish the plan in the Federal Register for public comment and consultation with non-Federal entities during development and implementation. The Federal agencies must submit a plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance. The Department of Housing and Urban Development must develop policies within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The plan establishes procedures for applicants with technical deficiencies in their Federal financial assistance application. Applicants must be promptly notified of deficiencies and given 7 days to correct them. The agency will continue to consider the application during this period, and if the deficiency is corrected within 7 days, the application will still be considered. The agency will continue to consider the application even if there is a technical deficiency, which may not impact eligibility for funding. The duties of the director are outlined in Section 6. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and system for Federal financial assistance programs, along with uniform administrative rules. The Director may designate a lead agency and working groups to streamline and simplify Federal financial assistance administrative procedures, improve coordination of information sharing, and enhance the quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. The Director may designate a lead agency and working groups to assist in carrying out responsibilities under this Act. Agencies must submit information for review upon request. The Director can exempt agencies from requirements if they have few financial assistance programs. A list of exempted agencies will be publicly available. The Director shall submit a report to Congress with recommendations for changes in law to improve Federal financial assistance programs within 18 months of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act. The evaluation, due within 4 years of enactment, will assess performance and coordination among agencies and governments, with input from various organizations. Federal agencies, State, local, and tribal governments, and nonprofit organizations are involved in implementing this Act. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

Federal agencies can gather information for reviewing the financial integrity of activities receiving Federal financial assistance.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

There is no judicial review of compliance with this Act, and no provisions create enforceable rights through administrative or judicial action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET.

This Act will be in effect upon enactment and will expire five years later.

SEC. 12. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS REGARDING FEDERAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE.

Congress suggests that Federal financial assistance should prioritize communities with high poverty and unemployment rates.
